mBEDEx-y4.memHandModelNotes: SW Gap project modeled this species without map units using only ancillary data as model components

references: Alvarez-Castaneda, S.T. 2005. Peromyscus melanotis. Mammalian Species 764:1-4.
Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
habitat_description: The Black-eared Deermouse (Peromyscus melanotis) occurs in Mexico and southern Arizona.  The American populations of this species are disjunct from the rest of the species and are poorly described.  Alvarez-Castaneda (2005) states they are “predicted to occur in isolated areas of eastern Sonoran mountains.”  In Mexico, they inhabit the pine-fir zone and intermixed grasslands in high mountains, but they are also known to inhabit canyons.  They like rocky areas, areas with zacaton grass, marshes, grassy and bushy areas in mesic deciduous and coniferous forests (Alvarez-Castaneda 2005).  The species is similar to P. maniculatus but is found at higher elevations than P. maniculatus in the fir and upper pine belts, slopes, and plains above tree lines.
